A covering maTerial or perisarc appeared wiThin 24 hours. AfTer The excess
perisarc was cuT away, Three aggregaTes formed parTial hydranThs wiTh several
proximal and disTal TenTacles and a hyposTome. These showed normal movemenTs
and conTracTion and circulaTion wiThin The coelenTeron. WiTh feeding, They
probably would have nof regressed buT developed inTo compleTe hydranThs. These
hydranThs formed in dishes ThaT had been leTT undisTurbed for several days,
suggesfing ThaT The aggregaTes had Time To develop a polariTy needed Tor
hydranTh TormaTion. The hydranThs developed from a bud or lobe in conTrasT To
developmenT in regeneraTion by conversion of a coenosarc area wiTh laTer emer-
sion from The perisarc.
MosT of The smooTh, spherical or lobed masses remained healThy and
aiive for more Than a week. The conTinuous perisarc may have creaTed a
pressure Tending To inhibiT ouTgrowTh from The cenTral mass. SomeTimes maTerial
wiThdrew from a lobe and became more concenTraTed. Debris usually occupied The
cenTer of The sphere wiTh cells locaTed around The circumference. HisTological
work would be necessary To see The kind and arrangemenT of cells; in living
Tissue They seem To be in Two layers as are The ecToderm and endoderm.
Wilson and HargiTT boTh describe a despecializaTion of cells during The
firsT few hours. lT was observed here ThaT some of The large brown endodermal
cells, each having large granules and a flagellum, moved shorT disTances and
appeared To break up. lT was noT possible To deTermine wheTher The flagellum
was The means of movemenT. BacTerial and proTozoan conTaminaTion prevenTed
sTudies of The cells for exTended periods so ThaT possible changes in inTersTi-
Tial cells could noT be followed.
The daT@ indicaTe ThaT dissociaTed coelenTeraTe cells have a very
|imiTed capaciTy for movemenT buT ThaT resTiTuTion of The fully organized
hydranTh can proceed if suTTicienT mass is presenT and The original organizaTion

GARRISON, HENRY QbservaTipns on puncTure effecTs on The
sioionyof Perophora viridis.
The purpose of Those experimenTs was fb observe The efTecTs of various
simple operaTions carried ouT on The sTolon oT Eerophora yiridis. ln all
experimenTs, glass rods were used To press off The circulaTion in The sTolon
while leaving The proToplasmic connecTion inTenT. ln various experimenTs The
sTolon was puncTured in order To deTermine The effecT, if any, on The growTh
paTTern of The sTolon.
Fresh Peroghora were used in all experimenTs. SegmenTs, approximaTely
a cenTimeTer in lengTh, were cuT and fasTened To The surface of Syracuse waTch
glasses wiTh a small amounT of vaseline. The secTions chosen were generally
Taken from The porTion of The sTolon which appeared To be growing well. AbouT
six secTions were placed in each dish. The Peroghora were Then placed in
running sea waTer aT abouT |90 C, and This medium was used ThroughouT The
experimenT. The sTolons grew ouT well in 4*5 days. A problem early encounTered
was The disposiTion of a layer of debris on The surface of The dishes, a facT
ThaT inTerfered wiTh The experimenT. IT was parTially circumvenTed by wrapping
The racks (used To hold The Syracuse dishes) in four Thicknesses of cheesecloTh.
